Mathematical and Bitwise Operators

These operate exactly like their counterparts for the built-in integer types.

Note that there is no operator~. Since the integer type doesn't have a fixed maximum size, there is no logical way to implement it.

Static Public Member Functions

Preconstructed integers

These return preconstructed integers with the values named by the functions. They are used internally, so that the most common values don't have to be constructed each time they're needed, but they are available to your own code as well.



static const integer & zero ()
static const integer & one ()

Detailed Description

The extended integer class.

This class implements the main integer type.

There are only a few member functions; most of the functionality is implemented using standalone functions.

Functions that start with an underscore (such as _make_unique) are intended for internal use only. They may change arbitrarily in future versions.

Definition at line 34 of file integer.cpp.

xint::integer::integer ( const integer &  b  ) 

Creates a copy of an existing integer.

Parameters:
[in] b An existing integer. If passed a Not-a-Number, it will create another Not-a-Number.
Note:
This library can use a copy-on-write technique, making copying (even of large numbers) a very inexpensive operation.

This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

) [inline]

Constructs a new integer object with the value of the built-in signed integer passed to it.

Parameters:
[in] n A number of type T.
Template Parameters:
T The type of n.

You can ignore the enable_if parameters, they are there only to tell the compiler what types it applies to.

This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

Definition at line 573 of file xint.hpp.

xint::integer::integer ( const std::string &  str,
size_t  base = 10 
) [explicit]

Create an integer from a string representation.

Parameters:
[in] str A string representation of a number.
[in] base The base of the number, or xint::autobase.
Exceptions:
xint::invalid_base if the base parameter is not between 2 and 36 (inclusive) or the constant xint::autobase.
xint::invalid_digit if the string contains any digit that cannot be part of a number in the specified base, or if there are no valid digits.
Remarks:
This will convert a string representation of a number into an integer. See the description of the xint::from_string function for details on its behavior.
This is the most common way to initialize values that are too large to fit into a native integral type.

This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

Definition at line 74 of file integer.cpp.

xint::integer::integer ( const not_a_number &  n  )  [explicit]

Creates an integer with the value of Not-a-Number.

Parameters:
[in] n An xint::not_a_number object (normally used as an exception class).
Remarks:
This is the official way to create an integer with the Not-a-Number value, if you ever wish to use that value for your own purposes.
See also:
The Not-a-Number Value

This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

int xint::integer::sign (  )  const

Tests the sign of *this.
